title.narrative: Civil Society Facility South Sudan

description.narrative: As CSF we believe that Sustainability of civil society and CSOs is about their ability to remain engaged in activities that are relevant to their constituencies. This will be achieved by focusing on institutional capacity building as opposed to just giving grants, facilitating partnerships between existing institutions, taking time to build trust and long-standing relationships, developing greater dialogue between citizens and government and a gradual long-term vision for capacity development. In doing so, CSOs will help build a more inclusive, democratic and pro-poor governance environment in South Sudan. This is in line with the CSF objective that civil society and CSOs need more than just funding in order to be sustainable.

LONG TERM GOAL More responsive and inclusive decision-making provides positive changes in the lives and wellbeing of communities/groups.
LONG TERM OUTCOME 1 Individual communities and groups affected by the programme have greater capacity to act on issues that affect them: Collectively identifying and prioritising issues; Acting together/more organised; Able to engage with and influence authorities/decision makers.
LONG TERM OUTCOME 2 Change in the knowledge, behaviours, policy, and practice of key authorities/decision makers affected by the programme that enhance their responsiveness to communities/groups: Government (National, State, County Payam / Boma); Traditional Authorities; International humanitarian and development actors; Private Sector.
SHORT TERM OUTCOMES 1. CSOs demonstrate improved organisational capacity 2. CSOs deepen their links with communities/groups 3. CSOs have increased their capacity to influence and engage with decision makers 4. CSOS form alliances to work on issues relevant to the needs and priorities of communities/groups
Supporting Communities

The Civil Society Facility (CSF) for South Sudan is a multi-donor fund established to strengthen the capacity of civil society organisations to bring about positive changes in the lives and well-being of communities and groups. It is funded by the Embassies of Norway, Sweden and The Netherlands, with the latter acting as lead donor. The CSF has a long-term outlook of 20 years based on five-year cycles. During a 12-month Inception Phase (April 2016 – March 2017), the donors and the Fund Manager created a programme that is flexible and scalable in its aim to support local civil society organisations in South Sudan.

participating-org.narrative: International NGO Training and Research Centre – INTRAC

5. CSOs deepen their linkages with communities/groups

description.narrative: NA

title.narrative: 5.2 % of CSOs supported by the CSF with representatives of communities and groups the CSO aims to represent being part of the CSO's decision making bodies (formal structure)

description.narrative: CSO employees also living in (one of) the community(ies) the CSO aims to represent do not count as representatives of the community in the decision making bodies

title.narrative: 5.3 % of CSOs supported by CSF collecting feedback from community members and sharing information on project activities with community members disaggregated by frequency

description.narrative: Collection of feedback and sharing information are seen as closely related, but independent activities. The disaggregation is consequently by frequency and by collecting feedback and sharing information

title.narrative: 5.1 % of CSOs consulting with the communities they are aiming to represent at least every 6 months and these communities confirming this consultation

description.narrative: The base for this percentage is the number of CSOs aiming to represent communities. Multiple communities represented by the same CSO count as one community. Both, CSO and the community(ies) it aims to represent have to confirm consultations

title.narrative: 3. Individual communities and groups affected by the programme have greater capacity to act on issues that affect them

description.narrative: NA

title.narrative: 3.2 % of (groups of) communities represented by a CSO perceiving an increase in their awareness of and communication with decision makers

description.narrative: The base for this percentage is the number of CSOs aiming to represent communities. Multiple communities represented by the same CSO count as one community. Data is collected at community level. The measure will be based on the majority opinion or average of the community members interviewed

title.narrative: 3.1% of (groups of) communities represented by a CSO perceiving a sufficient ability to jointly identify and prioritize issues (disaggregated by gender and age when possible)

description.narrative: The base for this percentage is the number of CSOs aiming to represent communities. Multiple communities represented by the same CSO count as one community. Data is collected at community level. The measure will be based on the majority opinion or average of the community members interviewed.

title.narrative: 3.3 % of (groups of) communities represented by a CSO having been within the past 6 months participating in engagement or influencing activities beyond consulting with communities

description.narrative: The base for this percentage is the number of CSOs aiming to represent communities. Multiple communities represented by the same CSO count as one community. In addition to the evidence from the CSO directly, one participant of the engagement or influencing activity or two community members having heard about this activity are seen as sufficient supporting evidence.

title.narrative: 2. Change in the knowledge, behaviours, policy, and practice of key authorities/decision makers affected by the programme that enhance their responsiveness to communities/groups

description.narrative: NA

title.narrative: 2.1 % of case studies of CSOs supported by the CSF where plausible contribution of CSOs to changes in the attitudes, behaviors, policy or practice of key authorities and decision makers was described by the CSO itself and confirmed by communities and/or authorities and decision makers

description.narrative: The percentage is calculated as case studies describing contributions of CSOs to changes which are confirmed by either community FGDs and/or decision maker KIIs divided by the total number of case studies in the Rolling Baseline (18) times 100

title.narrative: 7. CSOs form alliances between themselves and with other actors to work on issues relevant to the needs and priorities of communities
7.1 Frequency and description (from partners) of collaborative CSO activities between CSOs on issues relevant to the needs of communities disaggregated by formal and informal forms of collaboration

description.narrative: NA

title.narrative: 7.2 % of Outcome 1 CSOs having their success at influencing authorities or decision makers at least in part attributed to the CSOs alliances and cooperation with other CSOs (according to the CSO itself and confirmed by the authority or decision maker and/or by the community members)

description.narrative: The basis for this percentage is the number of CSOs in the Rolling Baseline for which plausible contribution to changes in the attitudes, behaviors, policy or practice of key authorities and decision makers was described by the CSO itself and confirmed by communities and/or authorities and decision makers (Outcome 2). At least partial attribution of this success to alliances with other CSOs has to be reported by the CSO itself and confirmed by the authority or decision maker and/or by the community members

title.narrative: 4. "CSOs demonstrate improved organizational capacity in the following areas: - Inclusive leadership - Strategic vision and direction - Good stewardship of resources - Tracking results and learning to improve - Resourcing and resilience
4.3 % of CSOs submitting complete progress and financial reports on time

description.narrative: Confirmed by the Facility and/or the Outreach Partner

title.narrative: 4.4 % of CSOs have secured additional funds from other sources

description.narrative: Confirmed by the Facility and/or the Outreach Partner

title.narrative: 4.5 % of CSOs being satisfied with the capacity development activities they receive as part of CSF and perceiving them as useful

description.narrative: Directly measured at CSO level

title.narrative: 4.1 % of CSOs demonstrating an increase in organizational capacity, classified by area (scorecards)

description.narrative: NOTE: While the exact wording of the score cards can be tailored towards the specific needs of each organization, the areas they cover need to be identical to aggregate results in each area across organizations.

title.narrative: 4.2 No and description of cases of enhanced organizational capacity where a plausible and corroborated/ triangulated contribution from the funding or CB efforts of the Facility can be demonstrated

description.narrative: The triangulation is based on CSO case studies and on Facility funded activities like trainings

title.narrative: 6. CSOs demonstrate increased capacity to influence and engage with decision makers

6.2 No of CSOs showing engagement and improved influencing strategy with decision makers (Outcome 5a) and attributing this change at least partially to the Facility's capacity development activities documented in case studies

description.narrative: The base for this percentage are the CSOs reporting increased communication and engagement with decision makers (Outcome 5a)

title.narrative: 6.1 No of CSOs supported by the Facility showing an increased engagement and improved influencing strategy with decision makers directly or via partners documented in case studies

description.narrative: The data will be collected at the CSO level with confirmation coming from either partners and/or decision makers
